Posts.Content: ... especially with their reply. Researchers identify seven types of breast cancer for more accurate prognosis" target="_blank">Article link - Researchers identify seven types of breast cancer for more accurate prognosis" target="_blank">Researchers identify seven types of breast cancer for more accurate prognosis The article was published on their facebook page. The last section talked about what the research meant for women - 5 times 'women' were mentioned, not once were men mentioned. Does the research not work for men??? When I questioned whether Breast Cancer was now gender-specific, they began their reply with " We focus on women in some topline wording on our website and other media because of the many more women diagnosed each year..." To me that does not give the right message to the media - that men suffer from it too. We're only 400 out of many thousands per year, but cant afford to be forgotten or dismissed, especially by a Cancer Charity.
Posts.Title: "Breast Cancer Campaign" - got everso slightly annoyed with this article...

Posts.Content: Hi debbiegabs (and others)...  When you say dont have a tattoo on same side as the 'op' does it matter which type of op and where? I've had bi-lateral mastectomy (May this year) and axial node removal on rightside (June). My right arm is being measured/monitored in case of lymphoedema occurring, but  a chance mention about cellulitis a year ago in one of my legs got the doc to check my legs - he says I have lymphoedema in both, wasnt expecting that !
Posts.Title: Tattoo after BC

Posts.Content: My experience is similar to that described by George &Jackie. - I had surgery first then chemo (last one was last Monday!) then Radio booked to start 10 Jan The 3 docetaxol sessions did affect me, but I feel it was more to do with the course of 7 daily injections I had to have post-docetaxol - bone pains esp feet knees sometimes jaw & teeth, tiredness, odd taste in mouth and only being able to taste hot or spicy food and cold drinks ( beer & curry, mmm :-) ) Dose up on painkillers for the bone pain, use the mouthwash and cold pineapple ( easy on the pineapple cos it may affect your tongue ) and it will be bearable - it's only a few days.... As for Radio, I'm told to treat as above - cream to safeguard the skin and it should be ok... really I'm dreading the daily journey to hospital more than the radio :) Cheers Russ
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Advice

Posts.Content: You can get Bio Oil on prescription - so you can be sure it's the proper stuff:-) Ask your doc for it…
Posts.Title: dry peeling sore skin

Posts.Content: WD40 or Duck Tape - the only two tools an experienced mechanic needs. If it moves and shouldn't - Duck Tape If it doesnt move and should - WD40
Posts.Title: dry peeling sore skin

Posts.Content: Windows is attempting to install Apology - Not Found.  Have a moan whenever you like, its good to get stuff out :-) Russ x
Posts.Title: I must say sorry

Posts.Content: I could go off some of you lot :-)
Posts.Title: Saw this and it made me smile

Posts.Content: Hi Admins moved the thread - you might find it here http://community.macmillan.org.uk/volunteering/noticeboard/f/214/p/65736/602516.aspx Cheers Russ
Posts.Title: What happened.

Posts.Content: As above, see a physiotherapist. I had great results after massaging from the Physio nurse, and do the exercises they give you to stretch the arm. Russ
Posts.Title: Cording in arm - any advice

Posts.Content: Hi some info in the previous replies I knew about, and some I didn't :) I asked my gp's nurse for flu jab when I went to get my Bio Oil prescription - she had to ask the doc but he agreed I could have the jab. The oil is helping with the surgery scars. Didn't know about bottled water, will avoid that for a while. Luckily, the only real effects I've been having is a few days of bloatedness and a bit of constipation. Had a bit of a 'furry' tongue but cleaned that with toothbrush to help. Can't help with advice on wigs/scarves as I don't bother with them - stil not quite used to seeing my reflection witha bald head but would probably look a bit funnier if I did have a wig or a scarf I think :-) Got my 3rd chemo tomorrow, so going on last 2 sessions, next week is my 'Sick Week' - should be ok by next weekend Cheers, Russ
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: Ha - was trying to keep the nail varnish a secret :-) As for deodorant, I use a roll on Aloe Vera from my local Forever Living agent
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: I couldn't do those injections - went to my gp's nurse each weekday for them to do it. They were very good about it and arranged for the district nurse to come to me on Sat & Sun. Cheers Russ
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: Hi AnneH - were you told to alternate which side you put the injections? My nurses kept a record of which side of my tummy was injected each day.
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: After reading what others go through, it seems the only 'normal' state is what happens to you. Everyone appears to have slightly different experiences, so if anything worries you talk to a doctor :)
Posts.Title: Which days are the most vulnerable.

Posts.Content: I've been ok from 10 days after the chemo until the next one.... guess it 'just depends'  :-)
Posts.Title: Which days are the most vulnerable.

Posts.Content: That's better Mrs, show em who's Boss! Guess we all have bad days/weeks, but make sure you come out the other side fighting :-) Russ x
Posts.Title: Is cancer not enough?!

Posts.Content: Hey Swan you're never alone on here - and if you think MAC can be a little 'too big' for you I can recommend Annabel's Angels , a new group but very good. And if you ever feel down in the dumps imagine what it's like being a male with breast cancer - the shock I've seen on mates faces is unreal :-) You made a good start reaching out on here - ask what you like when you like , someone will declare themselves to be your friend Russ
Posts.Title: back again @37

Posts.Content: I had my chest drained a few times after lymph node removal. Dr's and nurses reluctant to do it too often cos every puncturing is a potential infection hazard - didn't resort to wearing a bra but was convinced on occasions that I was getting a b-cup :) It did take a long while to heal inside, whIch obvs delayed the start of chemo treatment, but got there eventually. Cheers Russ
Posts.Title: Bruising after lymph node removal

Posts.Content: It does seem weird - though sometimes 'coincidences' like this occur all around us... after deciding on a new (next, not new) car or motorbike, suddenly they're everywhere, everyone's got one :-)  On the day in May this year when I was in hospital for double mastectomy, it was announced that Angelina Jolie had had the same op...   Russ
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer, Cancer and TV Shows

Posts.Content: I found talking to family / friends about BC and the surgery & treatment i'm going to get was helpful for me and helps them to understand it is not the beast it once was. Sorry I'm repeating myself but I do believe positivity is one of my strongest meds. But am painfully aware of other threads on BC that don't affect me - body shape, femininity etc Russ
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer, Cancer and TV Shows

Posts.Content: Thanks Flower24 :) I do have 2 long scars - a rather neat red line one side and a thicker one the other side where there were 2 ops - so far not missing my nipples :) Will try not to get any internal scarring… Russ
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer, Cancer and TV Shows

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian I can't deal with it any other way - it is what it is, I just have to make the best of it :) I have my 5th chemo next Monday, hopefully the 6th and final one mid-December then 3 weeks of Radio in January. Suppose I'm very lucky to be cared for by a great team at Royal Derby, no complaints whatsoever - I don't feel the support for me is any less than a woman would get (more opportunities for a laugh and joke about being a bit of a freak anyway ;) ) Cheers Russ
Posts.Title: Bruising after lymph node removal
